elements.content: Only a selected class of corrugated 2D hybrid lead halide perovskites exhibit broadband white-light emission from self-trapped excitons. Recently, we have discovered ultrastable layered lead halide photoemitters overcoming the stability problems of perovskites, despite in need of deep-UV irradiation to achieve photoluminescence quantum efficiency (PLQE) of over 10%. Herein, we have employed a robust, nonconjugated dicarboxylate ligand to pillar the cationic 1D [PbBr]+ chains. The unique corrugated stacking of [PbBr]+ chains facilitates the structural deformation to form self-trapped excitons, thus enabling an eightfold enhancement of PLQE over our previous reported bilayer bromoplumbate structures. The PLQE of 17.2% is not only among the highest in all of the layered lead halide white-light emitters, but overcoming the problem of our previous photoemitters requires deep-UV LED excitation. In addition, by tuning the stacking mode of the pillaring molecules, the chloride analog successfully incorporates a second photoluminescence center to the broadband emission from self-trapped excitons. The two-component emission strategy in [Pb2Cl2]­[O2C (C6H10)­CO2] offers the intrinsic photoemitter to exhibit tunable cold-to-warm white light upon different excitation lights. The materials demonstrate high chemical robustness over a wide pH range (3–9) and undiminished photoluminescence in air upon UV irradiation for 30 days. Density functional theory calculations indicate that the broadband emission of both materials are induced by the structural deformation of [Pb2X2]2+ (X = Cl/Br) inorganic connectivity, which offers self-trapped electrons from Pb–Pb dimerization and self-trapped holes from Cl–Cl pairing in the excited states.
elements.clean_text: Only a selected class of corrugated 2D hybrid lead halide perovskites exhibit broadband white-light emission from self-trapped excitons. Recently, we have discovered ultrastable layered lead halide photoemitters overcoming the stability problems of perovskites, despite in need of deep-UV irradiation to achieve photoluminescence quantum efficiency (PLQE) of over 10%. Herein, we have employed a robust, nonconjugated dicarboxylate ligand to pillar the cationic 1D [PbBr]+ chains. The unique corrugated stacking of [PbBr]+ chains facilitates the structural deformation to form self-trapped excitons, thus enabling an eightfold enhancement of PLQE over our previous reported bilayer bromoplumbate structures. The PLQE of 17.2% is not only among the highest in all of the layered lead halide white-light emitters, but overcoming the problem of our previous photoemitters requires deep-UV LED excitation. In addition, by tuning the stacking mode of the pillaring molecules, the chloride analog successfully incorporates a second photoluminescence center to the broadband emission from self-trapped excitons. The two-component emission strategy in [Pb2Cl2][O2C (C6H10)CO2] offers the intrinsic photoemitter to exhibit tunable cold-to-warm white light upon different excitation lights. The materials demonstrate high chemical robustness over a wide pH range (3-9) and undiminished photoluminescence in air upon UV irradiation for 30 days. Density functional theory calculations indicate that the broadband emission of both materials are induced by the structural deformation of [Pb2X2]2+ (X = Cl/Br) inorganic connectivity, which offers self-trapped electrons from Pb-Pb dimerization and self-trapped holes from Cl-Cl pairing in the excited states.

elements.content: Solid-state lighting (SSL), comprising light-emitting diodes (LEDs) coated with phosphors, is an emerging class of light sources with high-energy efficiency and long-term stability. However, the commercial YAG:Ce3+-based white LEDs have poor color-rendering indexes (CRIs) and low color stability due to limited coverage of the visible spectrum and the “halo” effect. Moreover, solid-state lighting systems that emit warm or cold white light must be installed as needed (e.g., warm white light for domestic lighting and cold white light for surgery uses). Thus, developing a single-phase, broadband white-light phosphor with a high CRI and tunable color temperature is a fundamental objective in the development of SSL technologies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Solid-state lighting (SSL), comprising light-emitting diodes (LEDs) coated with phosphors, is an emerging class of light sources with high-energy efficiency and long-term stability. However, the commercial YAG:Ce3+-based white LEDs have poor color-rendering indexes (CRIs) and low color stability due to limited coverage of the visible spectrum and the "halo" effect. Moreover, solid-state lighting systems that emit warm or cold white light must be installed as needed (e.g., warm white light for domestic lighting and cold white light for surgery uses). Thus, developing a single-phase, broadband white-light phosphor with a high CRI and tunable color temperature is a fundamental objective in the development of SSL technologies.

elements.content: Hybrid inorganic–organic metal halide perovskites occupying (110)-oriented corrugated layers or distorted (100)-oriented sheets are a rare class of intrinsic broadband white-light emitters, which are distinguished by their formation of self-trapped excitons from strong electron–phonon coupling. Although these single-source white-light emitters are a class of promising phosphors, most of layered perovskites suffer from two drawbacks: (i) low photoluminescence quantum yields (PLQEs, <2% for most of them) and (ii) moisture sensitivity. Lowering the metal halide dimensionality to 0D or 1D will substantially decrease the potential barrier for the formation of self-trapping excitons, thereby increasing the PLQEs. However, photoluminescence from this class of low-dimensional perovskites often exhibits limited coverage of the visible light spectrum, resulting in blue, yellow, or red photoluminescence. Moreover, the discrete lead halide clusters or chains are susceptible to hydrolysis, thus a decrease of photoluminescence intensity by >50% was observed upon 1 h irradiation at atmospheric condition.
elements.clean_text: Hybrid inorganic-organic metal halide perovskites occupying (110)-oriented corrugated layers or distorted (100)-oriented sheets are a rare class of intrinsic broadband white-light emitters, which are distinguished by their formation of self-trapped excitons from strong electron-phonon coupling. Although these single-source white-light emitters are a class of promising phosphors, most of layered perovskites suffer from two drawbacks: (i) low photoluminescence quantum yields (PLQEs, <2% for most of them) and (ii) moisture sensitivity. Lowering the metal halide dimensionality to 0D or 1D will substantially decrease the potential barrier for the formation of self-trapping excitons, thereby increasing the PLQEs. However, photoluminescence from this class of low-dimensional perovskites often exhibits limited coverage of the visible light spectrum, resulting in blue, yellow, or red photoluminescence. Moreover, the discrete lead halide clusters or chains are susceptible to hydrolysis, thus a decrease of photoluminescence intensity by >50% was observed upon 1 h irradiation at atmospheric condition.

elements.content: Recently, we have employed flexible α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates as structure-directing agents to template a class of cationic lead halide white-light emitters with high chemical stability and high photostability properties. These long-sought ultrastable lead halide materials exhibit undiminished broadband photoluminescence under continuous UV irradiation in air. However, only TJU-4 ([Pb2Cl2]­[O2C­(CH2)4CO2]) reached a PLQE of >10% when exposed to middle-UV irradiation (327 nm). Indeed, the emitted power and efficiencies of group III-nitride-based near-UV LED sources (>350 nm) are at least one order of magnitude higher compared with deep/middle-UV sources. Despite the bromide analog is suitable for near-UV excitation due to the suitable band gap, the thick [Pb2Br2]2+ bilayer motif with low corrugation limits the structural deformation and achieved a low PLQE of only ∼2%. Moreover, this class of cationic lead halide materials often has low CRI values (i.e., CRI of 68 for TJU-4), which is not acceptable for normal lighting applications. This is largely because of the deficiency in blue and/or red emissions, which are located at both ends of the visible spectrum. An ultrastable, single-component white-light phosphor with a high CRI (>80) and high stability is necessary for the development of eye-friendly lighting applications. Thus, it is imperative to advance this class of ultrastable lead halide materials toward near-UV-excited broadband photoemitters with high PLQE.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have employed flexible α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates as structure-directing agents to template a class of cationic lead halide white-light emitters with high chemical stability and high photostability properties. These long-sought ultrastable lead halide materials exhibit undiminished broadband photoluminescence under continuous UV irradiation in air. However, only TJU-4 ([Pb2Cl2][O2C(CH2)4CO2]) reached a PLQE of >10% when exposed to middle-UV irradiation (327 nm). Indeed, the emitted power and efficiencies of group III-nitride-based near-UV LED sources (>350 nm) are at least one order of magnitude higher compared with deep/middle-UV sources. Despite the bromide analog is suitable for near-UV excitation due to the suitable band gap, the thick [Pb2Br2]2+ bilayer motif with low corrugation limits the structural deformation and achieved a low PLQE of only ~2%. Moreover, this class of cationic lead halide materials often has low CRI values (i.e., CRI of 68 for TJU-4), which is not acceptable for normal lighting applications. This is largely because of the deficiency in blue and/or red emissions, which are located at both ends of the visible spectrum. An ultrastable, single-component white-light phosphor with a high CRI (>80) and high stability is necessary for the development of eye-friendly lighting applications. Thus, it is imperative to advance this class of ultrastable lead halide materials toward near-UV-excited broadband photoemitters with high PLQE.

elements.content: Herein, two new members of ultrastable lead halide hybrid emitters are identified, and then they are templated using a robust and nonconjugated trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (trans-1,4-chdc, –O2C­(C6H10)­CO2 –). The robust pillaring ligand template 1D cationic bromoplumbate chains that are stacked with strong corrugation achieve enhanced structural deformation than the previously reported bilayered counterpart. The resultant PLQE of 17.2% is among the highest in all of the layered lead halide white-light emitters. In addition, the chloride analog is the first ultrastable photoemitter to incorporate a second photoluminescence center to the broadband emission from self-trapped excitons. The resultant [Pb2Cl2 2+]­[−O2C­(C6H10)­CO2 –] is capable of producing tunable cold-to-warm broadband white-light photoluminescence via variations in excitation lights. The hybrid photemitter exhibits a tunable white-light color temperature that ranges from 3748 to 11034 K under different excitation wavelengths (e.g., 304–344 nm) and a CRI as high as 92 upon excitation at 322 nm.
elements.clean_text: Herein, two new members of ultrastable lead halide hybrid emitters are identified, and then they are templated using a robust and nonconjugated trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (trans-1,4-chdc, -O2C(C6H10)CO2 -). The robust pillaring ligand template 1D cationic bromoplumbate chains that are stacked with strong corrugation achieve enhanced structural deformation than the previously reported bilayered counterpart. The resultant PLQE of 17.2% is among the highest in all of the layered lead halide white-light emitters. In addition, the chloride analog is the first ultrastable photoemitter to incorporate a second photoluminescence center to the broadband emission from self-trapped excitons. The resultant [Pb2Cl2 2+][-O2C(C6H10)CO2 -] is capable of producing tunable cold-to-warm broadband white-light photoluminescence via variations in excitation lights. The hybrid photemitter exhibits a tunable white-light color temperature that ranges from 3748 to 11034 K under different excitation wavelengths (e.g., 304-344 nm) and a CRI as high as 92 upon excitation at 322 nm.

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of PbCl2, trans-1,4-chdc, and perchloric acid in DMF/EtOH produced colorless plate-like crystals of [Pb2Cl2 2+]­[−O2C­(C6H10)­CO2 –]­(TJU-10, TJU = Tongji University) (Figure S1). Slow cooling at a rate of 15 °C h–1 is necessary to facilitate the high-yielding synthesis, resulting in a high-purity crystalline structure. Perchloric acid is necessary for successful synthesis, performing as an acid to tune pH and as a stabilizer for hydrofluoric acid in zeolite synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The solvothermal reaction of PbCl2, trans-1,4-chdc, and perchloric acid in DMF/EtOH produced colorless plate-like crystals of [Pb2Cl2 2+][-O2C(C6H10)CO2 -](TJU-10, TJU = Tongji University) (Figure S1). Slow cooling at a rate of 15 °C h-1 is necessary to facilitate the high-yielding synthesis, resulting in a high-purity crystalline structure. Perchloric acid is necessary for successful synthesis, performing as an acid to tune pH and as a stabilizer for hydrofluoric acid in zeolite synthesis.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray crystallography reveals the structure of TJU-10 comprises slightly corrugated [PbCl]+ layers, which are coordinatively bridged by the anionic trans-1,4-chdc ligands, residing in the interlamellar region (a). In each [PbCl]+ plane, the adjacent 1D [PbCl]+ zigzag chains that propagating along the c-axis weakly interact with each other by forming [Pb2Cl2]2+ square units. The interchain Pb–Cl atomic distances are 3.119(3) Å, slightly longer than the widely accepted Pb–Cl bond lengths (∼2.84 Å, CSD) (Figure S2). All 1,4-chdc ligands are in e,e-trans conformation and are linked to the adjacent [PbCl]+ layers in a tilted direction (a). Both carboxylate ends of the 1,4-chdc molecules have one oxygen perpendicularly pointing toward the conjugated plane of the carboxylate group from the adjacent 1,4-chdc molecule (Figure S3a). The oxygens are in close proximity toward the carbon from the nearest carboxylate with a –OCO···COO– distance of 3.238(5) Å, contributing to the π-orbital interactions of the carboxylate groups.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray crystallography reveals the structure of TJU-10 comprises slightly corrugated [PbCl]+ layers, which are coordinatively bridged by the anionic trans-1,4-chdc ligands, residing in the interlamellar region (a). In each [PbCl]+ plane, the adjacent 1D [PbCl]+ zigzag chains that propagating along the c-axis weakly interact with each other by forming [Pb2Cl2]2+ square units. The interchain Pb-Cl atomic distances are 3.119(3) Å, slightly longer than the widely accepted Pb-Cl bond lengths (~2.84 Å, CSD) (Figure S2). All 1,4-chdc ligands are in e,e-trans conformation and are linked to the adjacent [PbCl]+ layers in a tilted direction (a). Both carboxylate ends of the 1,4-chdc molecules have one oxygen perpendicularly pointing toward the conjugated plane of the carboxylate group from the adjacent 1,4-chdc molecule (Figure S3a). The oxygens are in close proximity toward the carbon from the nearest carboxylate with a -OCO⋅⋅⋅COO- distance of 3.238(5) Å, contributing to the π-orbital interactions of the carboxylate groups.

elements.content: Crystallographic view of (a) TJU-10 and (b) TJU-11. Insets show the asymmetric Pb–X coordination environments. Cyan, blue, yellow, red, and gray spheres represents Pb, Cl, Br, O, and C atoms, respectively. H atoms are omitted for clarity. The insets highlight the coordination between Pb­(II) centers and halogen atoms.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystallographic view of (a) TJU-10 and (b) TJU-11. Insets show the asymmetric Pb-X coordination environments. Cyan, blue, yellow, red, and gray spheres represents Pb, Cl, Br, O, and C atoms, respectively. H atoms are omitted for clarity. The insets highlight the coordination between Pb(II) centers and halogen atoms.

elements.content: [Pb2Br2 2+]­[−O2C­(C6H10)­CO2 –] (TJU-11) forms under hydrothermal condition between PbBr2, trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid disodium salt (trans-1,4-chdcNa2), and hydrobromic acid (HBr). The addition of HBr provides a second Br source to form lead bromide layers, while also performing as an acid to tune the pH. In contrast to the zigzag chains in TJU-10, the 1D [PbBr]+ chains in TJU-11 are nearly straight with intrachain Pb–Br–Pb bond angles of 169.09(4)°. In addition, the 1D bromoplumbate linear chains are more discrete, occupying the nearest interchain Pb–Br distances of 3.37–3.50 Å that significantly exceed the accepted Pb–Br bond lengths (2.97 Å) (Figure S2). The [PbBr]+ chains are weakly stacked into loosely packed and corrugated [PbBr]+ slabs, which are pillared by trans-1,4-chdc ligands (b). PbII centers are coordinated with four intralayer Br and three O atoms from trans-1,4-chda molecules. Unlike TJU-10, the trans-1,4-chda ligands are well aligned in the same direction, leading to no close interaction between oxygens and carbons from the adjacent ligand moieties (Figure S2c).
elements.clean_text: [Pb2Br2 2+][-O2C(C6H10)CO2 -] (TJU-11) forms under hydrothermal condition between PbBr2, trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid disodium salt (trans-1,4-chdcNa2), and hydrobromic acid (HBr). The addition of HBr provides a second Br source to form lead bromide layers, while also performing as an acid to tune the pH. In contrast to the zigzag chains in TJU-10, the 1D [PbBr]+ chains in TJU-11 are nearly straight with intrachain Pb-Br-Pb bond angles of 169.09(4)°. In addition, the 1D bromoplumbate linear chains are more discrete, occupying the nearest interchain Pb-Br distances of 3.37-3.50 Å that significantly exceed the accepted Pb-Br bond lengths (2.97 Å) (Figure S2). The [PbBr]+ chains are weakly stacked into loosely packed and corrugated [PbBr]+ slabs, which are pillared by trans-1,4-chdc ligands (b). PbII centers are coordinated with four intralayer Br and three O atoms from trans-1,4-chda molecules. Unlike TJU-10, the trans-1,4-chda ligands are well aligned in the same direction, leading to no close interaction between oxygens and carbons from the adjacent ligand moieties (Figure S2c).

elements.content: Both TJU-10 and TJU-11 are synthesized with high yields (>75%) and phase purity, which is evidenced via experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns. These patterns match the simulated patterns from single-crystal data (Figure S3). Thermogravimetric analysis and ex situ thermodiffraction indicate that TJU-10 and TJU-11 are thermally stable up to 260 and 330 °C, respectively, in air (Figures S3 and S4). Moreover, both TJU-10 and TJU-11 demonstrate high robustness over a wide pH range (3–9), which also applies to organic solvents that were examined by incubation of the solids into a diluted HCl or NaOH solution or organic solvents for 24 h. No significant loss of diffraction peaks was observed in the PXRD, and a <0.1 wt % decrease in mass was observed after chemical treatment (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: Both TJU-10 and TJU-11 are synthesized with high yields (>75%) and phase purity, which is evidenced via experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns. These patterns match the simulated patterns from single-crystal data (Figure S3). Thermogravimetric analysis and ex situ thermodiffraction indicate that TJU-10 and TJU-11 are thermally stable up to 260 and 330 °C, respectively, in air (Figures S3 and S4). Moreover, both TJU-10 and TJU-11 demonstrate high robustness over a wide pH range (3-9), which also applies to organic solvents that were examined by incubation of the solids into a diluted HCl or NaOH solution or organic solvents for 24 h. No significant loss of diffraction peaks was observed in the PXRD, and a <0.1 wt % decrease in mass was observed after chemical treatment (Figure S3).

elements.content: The absorption spectrum of TJU-10 indicates a band gap of 3.37 eV (a and Figure S5). The total density of states (DOS) indicate that the dicarboxylate ligands significantly contribute to both the valence band maximum (VBM) and the conduction band minimum (CBM) (a) unlike the organoammonium cations in perovskites not contributing to the VBM and the CBM. This is presumably due to the formation of Pb-carboxylate chemical bondings in the cationic lead halide materials. Meanwhile, the other VBM and CBM are attributed to the full Cl 3p orbitals and empty Pb 5p orbitals, respectively. The calculated band gap (3.62 eV) is rather close to the experimentally observed value (3.37 eV) ().
elements.clean_text: The absorption spectrum of TJU-10 indicates a band gap of 3.37 eV (a and Figure S5). The total density of states (DOS) indicate that the dicarboxylate ligands significantly contribute to both the valence band maximum (VBM) and the conduction band minimum (CBM) (a) unlike the organoammonium cations in perovskites not contributing to the VBM and the CBM. This is presumably due to the formation of Pb-carboxylate chemical bondings in the cationic lead halide materials. Meanwhile, the other VBM and CBM are attributed to the full Cl 3p orbitals and empty Pb 5p orbitals, respectively. The calculated band gap (3.62 eV) is rather close to the experimentally observed value (3.37 eV) ().

elements.content: (a) Absorption spectra of TJU-10 (black dashed line) and photoluminescence spectra of cm-sized single crystals (red solid line) and μm-sized microcrystals (blue solid line) upon 344 nm excitation; (b) photo-images of TJU-10 under the irradiation of a 310 nm UV lamp (left) or a 365 nm UV lamp (right); (c) photoluminescence spectra of TJU-10 under different excitation wavelengths (304–344 nm); and (d) CIE chromaticity coordinates of pure white-light (pentagram) and TJU-10 (triangle) upon excitation at 304 nm (black triangle), 322 nm (red triangle), 324 nm (blue triangle), 328 nm (magenta triangle), and 344 nm (green triangle).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Absorption spectra of TJU-10 (black dashed line) and photoluminescence spectra of cm-sized single crystals (red solid line) and μm-sized microcrystals (blue solid line) upon 344 nm excitation; (b) photo-images of TJU-10 under the irradiation of a 310 nm UV lamp (left) or a 365 nm UV lamp (right); (c) photoluminescence spectra of TJU-10 under different excitation wavelengths (304-344 nm); and (d) CIE chromaticity coordinates of pure white-light (pentagram) and TJU-10 (triangle) upon excitation at 304 nm (black triangle), 322 nm (red triangle), 324 nm (blue triangle), 328 nm (magenta triangle), and 344 nm (green triangle).

elements.content: (a) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-10, (b) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the ground state along the a-axis, and (c) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the excited state along the a-axis. Pb–Pb and Cl–Cl distances of the nearest neighbouring atoms are highlighted; (d) temperature-dependent emission spectra of TJU-10 and (e) photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-10 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-10 microcrystals (red) measured at 550 nm.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-10, (b) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the ground state along the a-axis, and (c) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the excited state along the a-axis. Pb-Pb and Cl-Cl distances of the nearest neighbouring atoms are highlighted; (d) temperature-dependent emission spectra of TJU-10 and (e) photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-10 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-10 microcrystals (red) measured at 550 nm.

elements.content: Importantly, the excitation spectrum of TJU-10 demonstrates two maximum at 304 and 344 nm, owing to the presence of two photoluminescence components (Figure S6). Upon excitation at 344 nm, TJU-10 exhibits a broadband photoluminescence with a maximum at 550 nm with the presence of the low-intensity blue emission (400–450 nm) ( and Figure S7). Interestingly, lowering the excitation wavelength results in an obvious enhancement in the blue photoluminescence centered at 433 nm and a concomitant reduction in the intensity of the yellowish broadband photoluminescence (maximum at 550 nm) (c). Upon excitation at 324 nm, the hybrid emitter displays nearly identical maximum intensity for both photoluminescence bands, which resulted in the full coverage of the entire visible-light spectrum (400–760 nm) (c blue). Accordingly, the emission gives a correlated color temperature of 5635 K and an ultrahigh CRI value of 91, which is even comparable to the mixed-phosphor light sources ( and Table S3). Indeed, the Commission Internationale de l’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity coordinates of this emission are (0.33, 0.35), which is very close to that of pure white light (0.33, 0.33) (d). Moreover, the relative intensity of two emission components can be well-tuned by adjusting the excitation wavelength from 304 to 344 nm, thus achieving a correlated color temperature in the range of 3748–11034 K in a controllable fashion (d). For example, the single-component photoemitter exhibits either bluish “cold” white-light or “warm” white-light that is ideal for indoor illumination when a 310 nm-based or a 365 nm-based UV-lamp are used, respectively (b). More importantly, TJU-10 displays remarkably high photostablity in air (60% relative humidity; room temperature) with almost no change of emission intensity under continuous UV irradiation (67 mW/cm2; 365 nm) for 30 days (Figure S8). To show the ultrastable nature of our materials, we performed the identical UV-irradiation treatment of 1D lead halide perovskite photoemitters for comparison. However, after 24 h irradiation, a ∼60% decrease in the emission intensity was observed (Figure S9). In addition, no apparent decrease or change was detected in the emission band of TJU-10 after the chemical or thermal treatment because of its robust nature (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text: Importantly, the excitation spectrum of TJU-10 demonstrates two maximum at 304 and 344 nm, owing to the presence of two photoluminescence components (Figure S6). Upon excitation at 344 nm, TJU-10 exhibits a broadband photoluminescence with a maximum at 550 nm with the presence of the low-intensity blue emission (400-450 nm) ( and Figure S7). Interestingly, lowering the excitation wavelength results in an obvious enhancement in the blue photoluminescence centered at 433 nm and a concomitant reduction in the intensity of the yellowish broadband photoluminescence (maximum at 550 nm) (c). Upon excitation at 324 nm, the hybrid emitter displays nearly identical maximum intensity for both photoluminescence bands, which resulted in the full coverage of the entire visible-light spectrum (400-760 nm) (c blue). Accordingly, the emission gives a correlated color temperature of 5635 K and an ultrahigh CRI value of 91, which is even comparable to the mixed-phosphor light sources ( and Table S3). Indeed, the Commission Internationale de l'Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity coordinates of this emission are (0.33, 0.35), which is very close to that of pure white light (0.33, 0.33) (d). Moreover, the relative intensity of two emission components can be well-tuned by adjusting the excitation wavelength from 304 to 344 nm, thus achieving a correlated color temperature in the range of 3748-11034 K in a controllable fashion (d). For example, the single-component photoemitter exhibits either bluish "cold" white-light or "warm" white-light that is ideal for indoor illumination when a 310 nm-based or a 365 nm-based UV-lamp are used, respectively (b). More importantly, TJU-10 displays remarkably high photostablity in air (60% relative humidity; room temperature) with almost no change of emission intensity under continuous UV irradiation (67 mW/cm2; 365 nm) for 30 days (Figure S8). To show the ultrastable nature of our materials, we performed the identical UV-irradiation treatment of 1D lead halide perovskite photoemitters for comparison. However, after 24 h irradiation, a ~60% decrease in the emission intensity was observed (Figure S9). In addition, no apparent decrease or change was detected in the emission band of TJU-10 after the chemical or thermal treatment because of its robust nature (Figure S10).

elements.content:
Photophysical Properties of TJU-10 and TJU-11 Crystals<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> materials λex (nm) λem (nm) CCT (K) φ (%) CRI TJU-10 304 433 11034 20.0 n.d. 324 550 n.d. 2.7 91 344 550 3748 2.4 79 TJU-11 354 500 7644 17.2 81

λex is the excitation wavelength, λem is the wavelength at the emission maxima, φ is the external photoluminescence quantum efficiency, and CRI is the color-rendering index. n.d. = not determined.

Given the tunability and excellent photoluminescence performance of TJU-10, its two-component emission mechanism was evaluated. First, identical emission and decay profiles are observed in cm-sized single crystals and μm-sized microcrystals, confirming the intrinsic nature of our broadband white-light emitters (a and e). To confirm the broadband emission originating from the self-trapped excitons, temperature-dependent photoluminescence was performed from 77 to 357 K (d). Even at 77 K, a broadband and strongly Stokes-shifted photoluminescence emission band was observed, a characteristic of self-trapped excitons in many metal halide crystals. Moreover, a gradual decrease in emission intensity and a broadening in FWHM from 0.55 to 0.74 eV were observed with increasing temperature from 77 to 357 K, consistent with strong electron–phonon coupling (d). Assuming the harmonic lattice vibration, the phonon energy can be estimated by fitting the FWHM (excluding the high-energy ligand-based emission, Figure S7) using the following equation: Γ ( T ) = Γ 0 + Γ LO ( e E LO / k B T − 1 ) − 1 + Γ inh e − E b / k B T
elements.clean_text: Given the tunability and excellent photoluminescence performance of TJU-10, its two-component emission mechanism was evaluated. First, identical emission and decay profiles are observed in cm-sized single crystals and μm-sized microcrystals, confirming the intrinsic nature of our broadband white-light emitters (a and e). To confirm the broadband emission originating from the self-trapped excitons, temperature-dependent photoluminescence was performed from 77 to 357 K (d). Even at 77 K, a broadband and strongly Stokes-shifted photoluminescence emission band was observed, a characteristic of self-trapped excitons in many metal halide crystals. Moreover, a gradual decrease in emission intensity and a broadening in FWHM from 0.55 to 0.74 eV were observed with increasing temperature from 77 to 357 K, consistent with strong electron-phonon coupling (d). Assuming the harmonic lattice vibration, the phonon energy can be estimated by fitting the FWHM (excluding the high-energy ligand-based emission, Figure S7) using the following equation:     Γ  ( T )  =   Γ   0   +   Γ   LO     (   e     E   LO   /   k   B   T   - 1 )   - 1   +   Γ   inh     e   -   E   b   /   k   B   T     1

elements.content: Herein, Γ0 is the FWHM of the broadband emission band at 0 K, whereas the ΓLO and Γinh represent the contribution of electron–phonon coupling and inhomogeneous broadening of the FWHM, respectively. The best fit indicates the broadband emission is mainly induced by electron–phonon coupling (ΓLO of 153(3) meV vs Γinh of 176(5) meV) and a phonon energy (E LO) of 26(2) meV (Figure S11). The latter corresponds to a frequency of 209 cm–1, which resides within the range of Pb–Cl stretching frequency in TJU-10 (Figure S12).
elements.clean_text: Herein, Γ0 is the FWHM of the broadband emission band at 0 K, whereas the ΓLO and Γinh represent the contribution of electron-phonon coupling and inhomogeneous broadening of the FWHM, respectively. The best fit indicates the broadband emission is mainly induced by electron-phonon coupling (ΓLO of 153(3) meV vs Γinh of 176(5) meV) and a phonon energy (E LO) of 26(2) meV (Figure S11). The latter corresponds to a frequency of 209 cm-1, which resides within the range of Pb-Cl stretching frequency in TJU-10 (Figure S12).

elements.content: To further confirm the large Stokes-shifted broadband emission centered at 550 nm arising from the self-trapped states in the deformable TJU-10 lattice, DFT calculations were performed to investigate the structural deformation in the excited state. Because optical excitation of self-trapped excitons in metal halides is known to have intersystem crossing from singlet state to triplet state, excited-state structural deformation was applied to the spin-triplet exciton. Hole self localization was observed with Cl–Cl pairing in the distortion of the regular square [Pb2Cl2]2+ units, which lowers the Cl–Cl distances from 4.19 to 3.87 Å (b,c). The latter distance is close to the sum of two Cl– ionic radii, thus facilitating the formation of color centers (Cl2 –). The distortion of the square units elongates the Pb–Pb distance, yet the Pb–Pb dimerization was observed in the adjacent six-membered rings [Pb3Cl3]3+ with Pb–Pb distances between 3.37 and 3.49 Å. Meanwhile, all the Pb–Pb distances in the ground state TJU-10 are >4.00 Å. By contrast, no significant change was observed in the stacking mode of the interlamellar trans-1,4-chdc ligands, excluding their contribution to the broadband emission at 550 nm (Figure S13). The calculated excitation and emission energies (at the PBE level) are 3.92 and 2.38 eV, respectively (). These values correspond well with the experimental optical transition energies (3.60 eV for excitation energy and 2.25 eV for emission energy). These results suggest that the lattice deformation in TJU-10 introduces self-trapped electrons from Pb–Pb dimerization and self-trapped holes from Cl–Cl pairing with short-range bonding distances between the nearest neighboring ions.
elements.clean_text: To further confirm the large Stokes-shifted broadband emission centered at 550 nm arising from the self-trapped states in the deformable TJU-10 lattice, DFT calculations were performed to investigate the structural deformation in the excited state. Because optical excitation of self-trapped excitons in metal halides is known to have intersystem crossing from singlet state to triplet state, excited-state structural deformation was applied to the spin-triplet exciton. Hole self localization was observed with Cl-Cl pairing in the distortion of the regular square [Pb2Cl2]2+ units, which lowers the Cl-Cl distances from 4.19 to 3.87 Å (b,c). The latter distance is close to the sum of two Cl- ionic radii, thus facilitating the formation of color centers (Cl2 -). The distortion of the square units elongates the Pb-Pb distance, yet the Pb-Pb dimerization was observed in the adjacent six-membered rings [Pb3Cl3]3+ with Pb-Pb distances between 3.37 and 3.49 Å. Meanwhile, all the Pb-Pb distances in the ground state TJU-10 are >4.00 Å. By contrast, no significant change was observed in the stacking mode of the interlamellar trans-1,4-chdc ligands, excluding their contribution to the broadband emission at 550 nm (Figure S13). The calculated excitation and emission energies (at the PBE level) are 3.92 and 2.38 eV, respectively (). These values correspond well with the experimental optical transition energies (3.60 eV for excitation energy and 2.25 eV for emission energy). These results suggest that the lattice deformation in TJU-10 introduces self-trapped electrons from Pb-Pb dimerization and self-trapped holes from Cl-Cl pairing with short-range bonding distances between the nearest neighboring ions.

elements.content:
Comparison between DFT Calculation and Experimental Photophysical Properties<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t2fn1"></xref> DFT calculations experimental results materials E ex (eV) E em (eV) band gap (eV) E ex (eV) E em (eV) band gap (eV) TJU-10 3.92 2.38 3.62 3.60 2.25 3.37 TJU-11 3.89 1.80 3.11 3.50 2.48 3.22

E ex is the excitation energy; E em is the energy at the emission maxima.

After confirming the origin of the broadband emissive component centered at 550 nm for TJU-10, the contribution of high-energy blue emission is further investigated. The emission spectrum of trans-1,4-chdNa2 is measured at room temperature (Figure S14), which is well matched with the high-energy emissive profile of TJU-10. This is owing to the π-orbital interactions of the adjacent carboxylates, which are quite parallel and close to each other in VBM of TJU-10 (Figure S15). The interaction mode that having one oxygen perpendicularly pointing toward the conjugated plane of the other carboxylate has also been observed in trans-1,4-chdK2 (Figure S16), which has nearly identical emissive behavior with TJU-10 upon 304 nm excitation (Figure S14). Moreover, the lifetimes of TJU-10 excited upon 304 and 344 nm are 215 and 3.6 ns, respectively (e and Figure S17). The long lifetime (215 μs) is attributed to the transition of the intraligand π* → n from the free trans-1,4-chdNa2 ligand, whereas the decay lifetime of 3.6 ns is consistent with our initial assumptions regarding self-trapped excitons. Overall, it is clear that the extremely high CRI of TJU-10 upon excitation at 324 nm is achieved by a combination of two independent emission bands [Pb2Cl2]2+ and trans-1,4-chdc, respectively.
elements.clean_text: After confirming the origin of the broadband emissive component centered at 550 nm for TJU-10, the contribution of high-energy blue emission is further investigated. The emission spectrum of trans-1,4-chdNa2 is measured at room temperature (Figure S14), which is well matched with the high-energy emissive profile of TJU-10. This is owing to the π-orbital interactions of the adjacent carboxylates, which are quite parallel and close to each other in VBM of TJU-10 (Figure S15). The interaction mode that having one oxygen perpendicularly pointing toward the conjugated plane of the other carboxylate has also been observed in trans-1,4-chdK2 (Figure S16), which has nearly identical emissive behavior with TJU-10 upon 304 nm excitation (Figure S14). Moreover, the lifetimes of TJU-10 excited upon 304 and 344 nm are 215 and 3.6 ns, respectively (e and Figure S17). The long lifetime (215 μs) is attributed to the transition of the intraligand π* → n from the free trans-1,4-chdNa2 ligand, whereas the decay lifetime of 3.6 ns is consistent with our initial assumptions regarding self-trapped excitons. Overall, it is clear that the extremely high CRI of TJU-10 upon excitation at 324 nm is achieved by a combination of two independent emission bands [Pb2Cl2]2+ and trans-1,4-chdc, respectively.

elements.content: In contrast to that of TJU-10, the excitation spectrum of TJU-11 exhibits a prominent peak at 354 nm from [PbBr]+ layers with a rather weak and broad ligand-based contribution at 304 nm (Figure S6). Adjusting the excitation light from 304 to 354 nm, TJU-11 shows a single, broadband emissive component with negligible blue emission from the free trans-1,4-chda ligands (Figure S18). This phenomenon confirms that the emission from the free trans-1,4-chda ligand strongly depends on the stacking mode in the interlamellar region. Almost no ligand-based emission in TJU-11 is attributed to the lack of π-orbital interactions from the carboxylate groups in trans-1,4-chdc molecules (Figure S15). Upon 354 nm excitation, TJU-11 displays a cold broadband white-light emission with a maximum at 500 nm, a FWHM of 178 nm (0.86 eV), and a high external PLQE of 17.2% (a, ). The PLQE is significantly higher than most of the previously reported layered lead halide materials (up to 9–11%). More importantly, the near-UV excitation for TJU-11 is a substantial advance over TJU-4 (PLQE of 11.8%) requiring a middle-UV light (327 nm) excitation because of the much higher efficiencies of group III-nitride-based near-UV LED sources. Importantly, postthermal or chemical treatment TJU-11 exhibits the identical broadband emission, demonstrating its “inert” nature as the ultrastable photoemitter (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text: In contrast to that of TJU-10, the excitation spectrum of TJU-11 exhibits a prominent peak at 354 nm from [PbBr]+ layers with a rather weak and broad ligand-based contribution at 304 nm (Figure S6). Adjusting the excitation light from 304 to 354 nm, TJU-11 shows a single, broadband emissive component with negligible blue emission from the free trans-1,4-chda ligands (Figure S18). This phenomenon confirms that the emission from the free trans-1,4-chda ligand strongly depends on the stacking mode in the interlamellar region. Almost no ligand-based emission in TJU-11 is attributed to the lack of π-orbital interactions from the carboxylate groups in trans-1,4-chdc molecules (Figure S15). Upon 354 nm excitation, TJU-11 displays a cold broadband white-light emission with a maximum at 500 nm, a FWHM of 178 nm (0.86 eV), and a high external PLQE of 17.2% (a, ). The PLQE is significantly higher than most of the previously reported layered lead halide materials (up to 9-11%). More importantly, the near-UV excitation for TJU-11 is a substantial advance over TJU-4 (PLQE of 11.8%) requiring a middle-UV light (327 nm) excitation because of the much higher efficiencies of group III-nitride-based near-UV LED sources. Importantly, postthermal or chemical treatment TJU-11 exhibits the identical broadband emission, demonstrating its "inert" nature as the ultrastable photoemitter (Figure S10).

elements.content: (a) Absorption spectra of TJU-11 (black dashed line) and photoluminescence spectra of cm-sized single crystals (red solid line) and μm-sized microcrystals (blue solid line) upon excitation at 354 nm. The inset is the photoimage of TJU-11 microcrystals under the irradiation of a UV lamp (4 W, 365 nm). (b) CIE chromaticity coordinates of pure white-light and TJU-11 upon 354 nm excitation. (c) Photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-11 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-11 microcrystals (red) measured at 500 nm. (d, e) Crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Br2]2+ layer in (d) ground state TJU-11 and (e) excited state TJU-11 along the a-axis. The Pb–Pb and Br–Br distances of the nearest neighboring atoms are highlighted. (f) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-11 (total: green, Pb: black and red, Br: blue, trans-1,4-chdc: magenta).

The inset is the photoimage of TJU-11 microcrystals under the irradiation of a UV lamp (4 W, 365 nm). (b) CIE chromaticity coordinates of pure white-light and TJU-11 upon 354 nm excitation. (c) Photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-11 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-11 microcrystals (red) measured at 500 nm. (d, e) Crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Br2]2+ layer in (d) ground state TJU-11 and (e) excited state TJU-11 along the a-axis. The Pb-Pb and Br-Br distances of the nearest neighboring atoms are highlighted. (f) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-11 (total: green, Pb: black and red, Br: blue, trans-1,4-chdc: magenta).

elements.content: The broadband emission from TJU-11 has a significantly higher PLQE (17.2%) than TJU-10 (2.4–2.7%), which is probably due to two structural features. First, in contrast to the adjacent zigzag [PbCl]+ chains in TJU-10 having interactions to form [Pb2Cl2]2+ square units, the 1D haloplumbate chains in TJU-11 are more straight and separated. Indeed, the low-dimensional haloplumbate connectivity will enhance the electron–phonon coupling and lower the potential barrier of self-trapped excited states. Thus, the more discrete [PbBr]+ chains will facilitate the exciton self-trapping and enhance the efficiency of broadband emission. Second, each 2D [PbBr]+ layer in TJU-11 have two flat haloplumbate sheets consisting of every other [PbBr]+ chains (Figure S2d). Each given [PbBr]+ chain is located out-of-plane between two adjacent chains, forming the highly corrugated layers, which are similar to the (110)-oriented layered perovskites. Indeed, the highly corrugated lead halide layer with acute Pb–(μ-Br)–Pb angles allow for greater lattice distortion in the excited state (d,e). Overall, the rather discrete [PbBr]+ chains and the corrugated lead bromide layers contribute to the high PLQE of broadband emission from TJU-11.
elements.clean_text: The broadband emission from TJU-11 has a significantly higher PLQE (17.2%) than TJU-10 (2.4-2.7%), which is probably due to two structural features. First, in contrast to the adjacent zigzag [PbCl]+ chains in TJU-10 having interactions to form [Pb2Cl2]2+ square units, the 1D haloplumbate chains in TJU-11 are more straight and separated. Indeed, the low-dimensional haloplumbate connectivity will enhance the electron-phonon coupling and lower the potential barrier of self-trapped excited states. Thus, the more discrete [PbBr]+ chains will facilitate the exciton self-trapping and enhance the efficiency of broadband emission. Second, each 2D [PbBr]+ layer in TJU-11 have two flat haloplumbate sheets consisting of every other [PbBr]+ chains (Figure S2d). Each given [PbBr]+ chain is located out-of-plane between two adjacent chains, forming the highly corrugated layers, which are similar to the (110)-oriented layered perovskites. Indeed, the highly corrugated lead halide layer with acute Pb-(μ-Br)-Pb angles allow for greater lattice distortion in the excited state (d,e). Overall, the rather discrete [PbBr]+ chains and the corrugated lead bromide layers contribute to the high PLQE of broadband emission from TJU-11.

elements.content: Owing to the high PLQE of TJU-11, the mechanism of its broadband emission was examined using DFT calculations. The total DOS demonstrate a calculated band gap of 3.11 eV, which is close to the measured band gap (3.22 eV) using absorption spectroscopy (f and Figure S5). The VBM and CBM of TJU-11 are primarily attributed to the full Br 4p orbitals and empty Pb 6p orbitals, respectively. In addition, the dicarboyxlate ligands partially contribute to the VBM, which is most likely caused by the oxygen atoms of the carboxylates gaining electrons from Pb–O bonding. In contrast to TJU-10 having separated ligand-based band gap and [PbX]+-based band gap (based on absorption spectra, a and Figure S5), these two very mixed gaps in TJU-11 indicate a higher degree of covalency in Pb-carboxylate bonding. To note, the broadband emission energy of TJU-11 is slightly higher than that of TJU-10 despite the VBM (Br 4p) for TJU-11 occupying higher energy than the VBM (Cl 3p) for TJU-10. This is likely due to that the broadband emission from TJU-11 is primarily contributed by low-energy self-trapped electrons (Pb2 3+), whereas the self-trapped holes (X2 – and/or Pb3+) play a more important role in the emission from TJU-10.
elements.clean_text: Owing to the high PLQE of TJU-11, the mechanism of its broadband emission was examined using DFT calculations. The total DOS demonstrate a calculated band gap of 3.11 eV, which is close to the measured band gap (3.22 eV) using absorption spectroscopy (f and Figure S5). The VBM and CBM of TJU-11 are primarily attributed to the full Br 4p orbitals and empty Pb 6p orbitals, respectively. In addition, the dicarboyxlate ligands partially contribute to the VBM, which is most likely caused by the oxygen atoms of the carboxylates gaining electrons from Pb-O bonding. In contrast to TJU-10 having separated ligand-based band gap and [PbX]+-based band gap (based on absorption spectra, a and Figure S5), these two very mixed gaps in TJU-11 indicate a higher degree of covalency in Pb-carboxylate bonding. To note, the broadband emission energy of TJU-11 is slightly higher than that of TJU-10 despite the VBM (Br 4p) for TJU-11 occupying higher energy than the VBM (Cl 3p) for TJU-10. This is likely due to that the broadband emission from TJU-11 is primarily contributed by low-energy self-trapped electrons (Pb2 3+), whereas the self-trapped holes (X2 - and/or Pb3+) play a more important role in the emission from TJU-10.

elements.content: Each [Pb2Br2]2+ monolayer in the ground state TJU-11 exhibits obvious corrugation from the regular 2D square-grid-type architecture and demonstrates a higher tendency to induce structural distortion than the inorganic slabs in TJU-10 as well as our previously reported TJU-5 (Figure S2c). Accordingly, DFT calculations indicate larger structural deformation in the excited state of TJU-11. Both Br–Br pairing (3.38 Å) and Pb–Pb dimerization (3.20–3.21 Å) are observed in the calculated excited state (e). The atomic distances of TJU-11 in its excited state are not only significantly lower than the ground state (Pb–Pb of >4.47 Å and Br–Br of >4.34 Å) (d,e) but also smaller than the dimerized units of TJU-10 in its excited state. The shorter Pb–Pb distance in excited state TJU-11 also agrees with our earlier speculation that the broadband emission is largely contributed by self-trapped electrons (Pb2 3+). In addition, on the basis of the PLQEs and lifetimes (e and c), the radiative decay rates were calculated to be approximately 0.67 × 107 S–1 for TJU-10 and 0.15 × 107 S–1 for TJU-11, whereas the nonradiative decay rates of approximately 27.3 × 107 S–1 for TJU-10 and 0.72 × 107 S–1 for TJU-11, respectively. The lower nonradiative decay rates of TJU-11 along with atomic distances values from DFT calculations indicate that the excited state TJU-11 is more likely to form self-trapped excitons such as Pb2 3+ and Br2 –. More importantly, no obvious movement of the interlamellar dicarboxylate ligands were observed from ground state to excited state, confirming the origin of the broadband emissions is exclusively associated with the structural deformation of [Pb2Br2]2+ layers (Figure S20).
elements.clean_text: Each [Pb2Br2]2+ monolayer in the ground state TJU-11 exhibits obvious corrugation from the regular 2D square-grid-type architecture and demonstrates a higher tendency to induce structural distortion than the inorganic slabs in TJU-10 as well as our previously reported TJU-5 (Figure S2c). Accordingly, DFT calculations indicate larger structural deformation in the excited state of TJU-11. Both Br-Br pairing (3.38 Å) and Pb-Pb dimerization (3.20-3.21 Å) are observed in the calculated excited state (e). The atomic distances of TJU-11 in its excited state are not only significantly lower than the ground state (Pb-Pb of >4.47 Å and Br-Br of >4.34 Å) (d,e) but also smaller than the dimerized units of TJU-10 in its excited state. The shorter Pb-Pb distance in excited state TJU-11 also agrees with our earlier speculation that the broadband emission is largely contributed by self-trapped electrons (Pb2 3+). In addition, on the basis of the PLQEs and lifetimes (e and c), the radiative decay rates were calculated to be approximately 0.67 × 107 S-1 for TJU-10 and 0.15 × 107 S-1 for TJU-11, whereas the nonradiative decay rates of approximately 27.3 × 107 S-1 for TJU-10 and 0.72 × 107 S-1 for TJU-11, respectively. The lower nonradiative decay rates of TJU-11 along with atomic distances values from DFT calculations indicate that the excited state TJU-11 is more likely to form self-trapped excitons such as Pb2 3+ and Br2 -. More importantly, no obvious movement of the interlamellar dicarboxylate ligands were observed from ground state to excited state, confirming the origin of the broadband emissions is exclusively associated with the structural deformation of [Pb2Br2]2+ layers (Figure S20).

elements.content: Two new members of ultrastable lead halide structures have been templated using photoactive rigid organic ligand, which exhibit intrinsic broadband white-light emission. Among them, the two-component emission strategy in TJU-10 enables an ultrahigh CRI of up to 92, which is among the highest in intrinsic white-light emitters. TJU-11 achieves the first ultrastable near-UV-excited broadband white-light emitter with a moderately high PLQE of 17.2%, owing to its unique cationic bromoplumbate chains stacked with high corrugation. DFT calculations indicate the broadband emissions originate from the Pb–Pb dimerization and Cl–Cl pairing in [Pb2X2]2+ (X = Cl/Br) layers. We believe that crystal engineering of these intrinsic, ultrastable lead halide photoemitters offers promising possibilities in the development of high-performance single-component white-light phosphors.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two new members of ultrastable lead halide structures have been templated using photoactive rigid organic ligand, which exhibit intrinsic broadband white-light emission. Among them, the two-component emission strategy in TJU-10 enables an ultrahigh CRI of up to 92, which is among the highest in intrinsic white-light emitters. TJU-11 achieves the first ultrastable near-UV-excited broadband white-light emitter with a moderately high PLQE of 17.2%, owing to its unique cationic bromoplumbate chains stacked with high corrugation. DFT calculations indicate the broadband emissions originate from the Pb-Pb dimerization and Cl-Cl pairing in [Pb2X2]2+ (X = Cl/Br) layers. We believe that crystal engineering of these intrinsic, ultrastable lead halide photoemitters offers promising possibilities in the development of high-performance single-component white-light phosphors.

λex is the excitation wavelength, λem is the wavelength at the emission maxima, φ is the external photoluminescence quantum efficiency, and CRI is the color-rendering index. n.d. = not determined.

The insets highlight the coordination between Pb­(II) centers and halogen atoms.

cln_elements.content: (a) Absorption spectra of TJU-10 (black dashed line) and photoluminescence spectra of cm-sized single crystals (red solid line) and μm-sized microcrystals (blue solid line) upon 344 nm excitation; (b) photo-images of TJU-10 under the irradiation of a 310 nm UV lamp (left) or a 365 nm UV lamp (right); (c) photoluminescence spectra of TJU-10 under different excitation wavelengths (304–344 nm); and (d) CIE chromaticity coordinates of pure white-light (pentagram) and TJU-10 (triangle) upon excitation at 304 nm (black triangle), 322 nm (red triangle), 324 nm (blue triangle), 328 nm (magenta triangle), and 344 nm (green triangle).

cln_elements.content: (a) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-10, (b) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the ground state along the a-axis, and (c) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the excited state along the a-axis. Pb–Pb and Cl–Cl distances of the nearest neighbouring atoms are highlighted; (d) temperature-dependent emission spectra of TJU-10 and (e) photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-10 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-10 microcrystals (red) measured at 550 nm.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-10, (b) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the ground state along the a-axis, and (c) crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Cl2]2+ layer in TJU-10 at the excited state along the a-axis. Pb-Pb and Cl-Cl distances of the nearest neighbouring atoms are highlighted; (d) temperature-dependent emission spectra of TJU-10 and (e) photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-10 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-10 microcrystals (red) measured at 550 nm.

cln_elements.content: (a) Absorption spectra of TJU-11 (black dashed line) and photoluminescence spectra of cm-sized single crystals (red solid line) and μm-sized microcrystals (blue solid line) upon excitation at 354 nm. The inset is the photoimage of TJU-11 microcrystals under the irradiation of a UV lamp (4 W, 365 nm). (b) CIE chromaticity coordinates of pure white-light and TJU-11 upon 354 nm excitation. (c) Photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-11 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-11 microcrystals (red) measured at 500 nm. (d, e) Crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Br2]2+ layer in (d) ground state TJU-11 and (e) excited state TJU-11 along the a-axis. The Pb–Pb and Br–Br distances of the nearest neighboring atoms are highlighted. (f) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-11 (total: green, Pb: black and red, Br: blue, trans-1,4-chdc: magenta).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Absorption spectra of TJU-11 (black dashed line) and photoluminescence spectra of cm-sized single crystals (red solid line) and μm-sized microcrystals (blue solid line) upon excitation at 354 nm. The inset is the photoimage of TJU-11 microcrystals under the irradiation of a UV lamp (4 W, 365 nm). (b) CIE chromaticity coordinates of pure white-light and TJU-11 upon 354 nm excitation. (c) Photoluminescence decay curve of cm-sized TJU-11 single crystals (black) and μm-sized TJU-11 microcrystals (red) measured at 500 nm. (d, e) Crystallographic view of a single [Pb2Br2]2+ layer in (d) ground state TJU-11 and (e) excited state TJU-11 along the a-axis. The Pb-Pb and Br-Br distances of the nearest neighboring atoms are highlighted. (f) Density of states (DOS) of TJU-11 (total: green, Pb: black and red, Br: blue, trans-1,4-chdc: magenta).

metadata.title:
Robust, Cationic Lead Halide Layered Materials with
Efficient Broadband White-Light Emission
